instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-2936 - Works but
threads.message:
You cannot have backlight with 12V on the output!

Do a PRAM reset, then:
First check SMC_LID, then check BKL_EN and BKL_PWM they should all be high. Check corrosion under/around the LP8550

U9701 Looks clean

threads.title: 820-2936 - Works but
threads.message: BKL_EN should be at least 2.6V. It is a simple resistor divider, so either R9731 is dead or the LP8550 is pulling it down. First check resistance to GND on BKL_EN, if it is less than lets say 60K the LP8550 is dead.

threads.title: 820-2936 - Works but
threads.message: I just replaced 9731 and LP8550 and still the same.

threads.title: 820-2936 - Works but
threads.message:
Q9706

Pin 1 : Start 3 and drop to 0 - PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR
Pin 2 : Start 3 and drop To 0 - PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR
Pin 3 : 12.22v - PPBUS_EN_DIV
Pin 4 : 12.60v - PPBUS_SO_LCDBKLT_FUSED
Pin 5 : 2.60 and drop - PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR
Pin 6 : 0.64 - PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR

threads.title: 820-2936 - Works but
threads.message:
Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET meaning it won't open unless the voltage on pin 3 is less than pin 4. 

R9788/R9789 is a voltage divider designed to send 5v to pin 3 of Q9706, so that it can turn on. However, it can only function as a voltage divider if the bottom resistor, R9789 has a path to ground, or else it will just send pin 4's 12.6v to pin 3 of Q9706. 

Q9707 determines whether R9789 gets to have a path to ground. This is a dual N channel MOSFET - it will allow power from source to drain when the voltage on the gate is higher or the same as the voltage on the source. Here the source is ground, which is 0, so anything on the gate will likely open it. 

So one of four things is occuring here.

1) C9782 is shorted and fucked, causing 12v to always be on pin 3 of Q9706.

2) R9789 is corroded/burned/bad.

3) LCD_BKLT_EN or BKLT_PLT_RST_L are missing <--- this is usually the case when the machine does not see the screen

4) Q9707 is fucked/bad.

5) Q9706 is fucked/bad shorting pins 3 and 4 together.

Seeing as you claimed you had no image, we should be troubleshooting no image rather than no backlight I feel. However, since you said you had backlight with 12v on backlight, which is impossible, I have no idea what it is you are seeing at this point, as the light will not turn on without 26-27v on this model...

threads.title: 820-2936 - Works but
threads.message:
WAIT WTF!!! I just watched the video and the backlight turns on! How else do you think the Apple logo lights up??? This means all your measurements are BULLSHIT.
The backlight works, the LCD is just not making an image. This is an LVDS issue. Measure all LVDS lines on diode mode. I bet L9080 is missing/damaged or the connector is fucked.

threads.title: 820-2936 - Works but
threads.message:
What you say you have and the actual measurements you have conflict with each other to the point where I don't believe any of your measurements. They are either mistyped, from the wrong point, or something. Are you removing the LCD to take your measurements or something?

I would ask you to measure voltage at pins 2/3 of the LCD connector but if you are saying you have 12v with backlight at backlight output I Can't trust your measurements and this is pointless.

First you need 3.3v at pins 2/3 of the LCD connector.

Then you need a known working LCD & LCD cable

Then you need L9080 to be good. Try a different L9080 and make sure it is soldered properly. 

I have no idea what to suggest for this case if you are providing wrong measurements. We really base our support on what you tell us, and if what you tell us is not physically/electrically possible, there's not much we can do to help you.

threads.title: 820-2936 - Works but
threads.message:
Your measurements do not reflect a working backlight, but whatever backlight is working.

The issue now is a black screen with backlight and that is usually an LVDS issue. As I asked before measure all LVDS lines on diode mode and post values. Pin 8,9,11,12,14,15,17,18. This is with the board OFF and LCD UNPLUGGED!

threads.title: 820-2936 - Works but
threads.message:
With charger plugged in, measure voltage at these points:
R6990, pin 1
R6990, pin 2
D6990, pin 3

It is VERY IMPORTANT that you figure out how to provide real measurements. When you were measuring 12v at pin 22 of the LCD connector, but saying it had backlight, do understand we are not trying to insult you by saying that measurement is bullshit. It is just fact - it is like saying I get 2v on my incandescent lightbulb socket but I see a light.. it is not possible.

Once you have sorted out taking voltage measurements with the mater, tell us what you get there.

threads.title: 820-2936 - Works but
threads.message: ppbus_g3h isn't even the main issue here. the issue is he says he has pp3v42_g3h on the battery, but not on the charger, but there is 16v input to the PP3V42 regulator. that is impossible.
